Russia





Andrey Kazanskiy
2D artist and flash animator.
Would love to know English, playing The Identity Quest
Russia



If you’ve read that far, you are our hero.Thank you
very much!
Risks and challenges
Frankly speaking, since our team is incomplete and
unexperienced in video games development, we can run quite a few risks on the
way even if we are able to raise a considerable sum.
The main issue is to find the right people to join us
in our journey. The scouting/hiring process may put off the estimated delivery
time.
However, we believe that if you consider the project
as worthy, as we think it is, and support us, we will make sure to make it a
reality.

story:
Seventeen years of midwifery practice and many summers chatting to
student midwives have led me to believe there are glaring gaps of
necessary knowledge in present midwifery training.

I am proud to be part of this new project that will train with-women
midwives in traditional skills and support newly trained midwives who
before felt unprepared.
We will hold a space for the brave midwives previously persecuted around the globe
to share their infinite wisdom.


Our school will be in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada Mountains,
Southern Spain.
The fertile land is abundant with oranges, lemons, almonds and olives.
Year round sunshine and gushing water from the 100 year old irrigation
system enable us to grow food. We will take studies back to a basic
wisdom. Living on the land, nurtured and inspired students and teachers
will flourish from the earth up.

We have gathered the sharpest, most passionate minds in midwifery to

create a centre of wisdom away from modern medicine, protocol and
insurance issues which stop true midwifery from flourishing as a profession.
Rather than fighting a non functioning system, we are creating a new
paradigm........ Starting afresh.

***

The first year long apprenticeship began in October 2014.  8 full-time students are living and learning at camp Luna (as named by the students!) and we are enjoying the wisdom of teachers from around the world.

People want the space passionately....

We need to find €15,000 to complete the school infrastructure.

This will be spent on our building team who are working so hard to
create this stunning space.
We are lucky enough to have Steve James as our designer and project
manager with a dedicated team of volunteer builders.

The money is needed for feeding the gang, a salary for Steve
and pocket money for the volunteers. Costs for the general
infrastructure are €650 a week to keep us rocking and if we plough on
we reckon we will finish by autumn.....

We urgently need to buy the remaining roof materials (we already bought
the large roof beams)…
We have been donated a fabulous Land Rover to use during the
build, but we have to put diesel in it....

Please trust every penny will be used wisely.


A detailed list of needs and wants can be found at the end of this
information.


Donate generously to create a ground breaking community of birth
revolutionaries!

***

Da-A-Luz has existed for more than 15 years...Women have come to birth their babies with nature and a team of lay midwives.
Aspiring birth workers have come to learn skills, be nurtured and take
their knowledge back to their communities.
The Da-A-Luz project counsels women through miscarriage, birth trauma
and termination, being a point of contact for non-judgmental and loving
support in the community.
Our Birth Rocks and Essence of Birth retreats have been an inspiration
to spirit and mind for many beautiful women struggling to work in a
system that does not support them.
Da-A-Luz also tours Europe in the fabulous Big Black Truck with a
geodesic dome dedicated to educating parents in all their birth
choices. We wow the festivals with our funky space, this year sponsored
by Lush and Mike Flannagan. Our workshops for both pregnant women and
birth professionals change lives.

Vanessa Brooks, founder and project leader is active with the Global
Midwifery Council and works with the Midwifery Today European
Conferences, helping to turn heads to towards a new yet ancient
birthing culture.

***

What Are We Doing?
We are building a school dedicated towards creating a new paradigm in
midwifery education - women based learning. Away from the belief that
birth is merely a medical event.

We are creating a learning space for wise women around Europe and a
sanctuary for those who feel unsupported by a medicalised and
fragmented system.

What Have We Got Already?


We have already started building with the help of a donation from Antje
Martje, a midwife from the Netherlands and an incredible offer from
ecobuilder Steve James who is our architect. We have already built the
foundations and first few feet of wall and prepared all the wood and
infrastructure to start the final push to finish the space for Spring.
Nick Price, dry stone waller teaches the team of volunteers, who have
given their time for food and nurturing in the heat of the Alpujarras
mountains.
We have a community of beautiful folk who are working hard to make this
vision come true.
We have a group of brave and wise teachers from around the world lined
up to teach.
We are a third way through our first year of study.

Our Vision



Da-A-Luz is building a sacred space that will hold a strong tribe of
teachers dedicated to bringing gentle birth back to mama and babe..oh and papa
too of course.

NEEDS
1) These are our urgent, immediate costs:
•  Wages and food for build crew-
Volunteers - €25/wk plus food and lodging
•  Building materials for roof and outer walls
•  Doors, windows
•  Interior finishing (wood burner system etc)
2) Beyond the building of the school, wider site equipment and
infrastructure are needed.  Any surplus funds will flow in this
direction:
•  Dedicated site vehicle
•  Alberca (large water storage tank) x2
•  Canvas cover for geodesic dome (currently temporary teaching space,
when the school is finished this dome will be the student recreational
space in winter and travelling workshop space in summer)

WANTS
If you are generous beyond our wildest dreams, we can make our space
luxuriously comfortable and gorgeous:
•  Student compost toilet, shower and fully equipped kitchen
•  Website update
•  Beautiful things – hangings, rugs, artwork, cushions, drapes, candle
lamps etc
•  Solar lights
•  Paint and brushes

HELP

We would love a dedicated childminder / playgroup leader / ‘unschooling
not-teacher’ to come live with us…

Please give generously:
Press the donate button at - www.da-a-luz.co.uk
Via Paypal -vanessadaaluz@yahoo.co.uk

Follow our progress on Facebook - Da-a-Luz Holistic Birth
Or come visit us on site near Orgiva, Southern Spain.

EVEN IF YOU CANNOT AFFORD TO GIVE, PLEASE DO SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN AMONGST YOUR NEAREST AND DEAREST SO THAT WE CAN REACH OUR DREAMS!

***

Quotes/References:

Nicola Mahdiyyah Goodall…
“It's absolutely essential that we prepare birthkeepers to walk with
women on their journey whichever turn it takes. Much of the available
training prepares the women to fill out paperwork, watch their back for
investigation, work as obstetric nursing staff or deliver interventions
and drugs with little room for gentle, patient birth care. With gentle
birth we create unfathomable love and strong families and I truly
believe the warrior birthkeeper is guardian of this saving grace.”

Flo…
“Evidence of true midwifery is now hard to see in contemporary
maternity services around the world. Women, midwives, families and
whole cultures bear the brunt of the violence of institutionalised and
over medicalised pregnancies and births. A new midwifery school will
counter the trend towards alienated birthing environments, and help
work towards helping those who care about how life is born”.

Melymel…
“We, midwifes, are trained as technology extensions, and not for
looking into the women's eyes. We, humanhood, have lost the confidence
on the women's body and their natural strength. We, mothers, want a
silent midwife by our side that we can trust in and be left in peace
with our own bodies, with our own labours, with our own babies...
Because we know how to do it. Just keep fear far from our side.
***Thanks for creating this place***”

Vanessa Brooks...
"I truly believe the way we birth and the way we die are sacred events.
That it is essential to the next generation that we step out of the
present system which is crushing the spirits of midwives and mothers
all over the world. And that we joyfully create a new way."

Georgina Mueller…

“I am pregnant with my 2nd and I have find with the last and this that
nearly all the midwives I have come in contact with have little or no
knowledge of natural and home birth. I do not feel I have been given
any empowerment to think my body and mind can do it. It has left me
nervous and a little scarred. I had one older wiser lady who was great
but in minority.”

Jude Horscraft…
"So looking forward to seeing the new Da a Luz sanctuary... A place to
recharge and nurture the souls of those that give themselves to
midwifery"

Umm Surur…
“I'm a mother of two little princeses who borned at home, I'm studying
at the university, want to become a midwife... but in this system I
just found fear and nonsense, actually, sometimes it is against nature,
against humanity. I'm looking forward to finish this step to start with
the real knowledge. I know, maybe I'm just working for a piece of paper
but I hope after this I can help girls, women, pregnants, midwifes,
humans... from inside to outside, maybe as a bridge. Would be beautiful
to act as a bridge, so spirituality could pass through in all that
concerns to birth, sexuality, been a mum or dad, teenager or baby.
Would be nice to have a place in earth, and even more if this place is
in Alpujarras!, for sharing ancestral knowledge and experiences...
Because this knowledge must be planted in every heart. ¡It's so
Important! We have to listen our hearts, allowing spiritual births so
we grow spiritual humans who respects the essence of LOVE.”

***

A WORD FROM OUR DESIGNER, STEVE JAMES.....



Above: Steve and the building team take a break from preparing timbers
to pose for the camera.  For up to date photos of the build follow us
on Facebook: Da-a-Luz Holistic Birth
"I was drawn to this inspiring project for several reason. If we are to
truly support a saner future, we must work together to build the
essential facilities to replace the crumbling infrastructure of this
ever more bankrupt and dysfunctional society. Likewise to refuse its
brutal, deadening ugliness by incorporating beauty and conscious
geometry to enhance the functionality of public or consecrated spaces
such as these. Care taken in design and construction is repaid many
times over, from the pride and self-confidence of all those creating
the building, to the focused energies manifesting in the space,
especially with such an intense and crucial experience as birth. Our
arrival in this world must be managed safely and sensitively, but also
celebrated. Temples where once centres of learning as well as worship.
If we seek wholeness then surely a training centre for natural midwives
may also honour She who births all?

With this in mind, the groundplan uses the egg, as symbol of birth,
protection, femininity and nourishment. Anciently utilised in the shape
of amphorae and ice houses, the main stone chamber, the pool within,
and the overall footprint all follow this pattern, with other spaces,
library, kitchen etc nestling under the extended reciprocal roof. Using
traditional techniques, the Guadalfeo river stones are laid and
mortared with locally dug red clay mixed with chumbo cactus juice to
strengthen the bond. The main columns are from huge eucalyptii felled
right behind the site, some of them taking eight men to lift. The
center of the twelve meter reciprocal roof can be opened up to let the
sky and stars enter the central chamber directly, or closed for warmth
during the winter months.

When required the centre of the floor lifts to reveal the birthing
pool, formed in Tadelakt, a Morroccan waterproof, lime-based finish
burnished with natural waxes to resemble polished marble. Shaped by
experience to accommodate both midwife and birthing mother in maximum
comfort, the water is heated by the wood-fired burner in the adjacent
kitchen, whose flue also runs buried in a cob channel around the
perimeter of the chamber, a simple form of hypocaust. Opposite the
entrance is the hearth, both for heating and an altar to focus some of
the other activities this flexible space will be used for.

The library has large east facing windows for early morning solar gain,
and can accommodate eight students, the kitchen is open on one side to
the large shady veranda, floored with the plentiful local marble
offcuts, where meals can be taken in comfort, essential in this region
where summer temperatures can easily reach 48C. The students will live
and study together, sharing this space and the bounty of the
surrounding landscape, overflowing with fruits and herbs, all watered
by the ancient aquecia system which brings the high Sierra meltwater in
small channels built of rock and earth for miles across this stunningly
rugged terrain, filling the pool at the heart of this temple. A centre
which may serve as inspiration for many similar endeavours as we
reclaim responsibility for our own well-being, and lay these much
needed foundations for our children by helping them first draw breath
in peace, beauty and reverence.
Blessings
Steve

***

Please give generously:
Press the donate button at - www.da-a-luz.co.uk
Via Paypal -vanessadaaluz@yahoo.co.uk

Follow our progress on Facebook - Da-a-Luz Holistic Birth
Or come visit us on site near Orgiva, Southern Spain.

EVEN IF YOU CANNOT AFFORD TO GIVE, PLEASE DO SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN AMONGST YOUR NEAREST AND DEAREST SO THAT WE CAN REACH OUR DREAMS!

story:
Our Mission

The mission of Entrepreneurship Educational Services (EES), Inc. and its partners is:

To provide animated, highly interactive, online entrepreneurship curricula anytime, anywhere.

Teaching financial literacy is the essence of our internet instructional resources and ongoing services for secondary education, home schooled, and encore entrepreneurs.

The Problem

Aspiring entrepreneurs, regardless of their stage in life, face many challenges.

·  Most graduating seniors enter the workforce financially illiterate

·  80% of educators admit to lacking the skills necessary to teach financial literacy courses

·  Homeschool parents struggle to find quality curriculum for their students

·  Encore entrepreneurs are in need of an affordable, yet flexible curriculum to fit their lifestyle needs

The ERO™ Solution

Entrepreneurship Educational Services (EES), Inc. has accepted the challenge to provide a web-based curriculum to address these needs.

The Entrepreneurial Recipe Online (ERO) ™ is a revolutionary new online learning program designed to inspire and educate students in the fundamentals of mastering financial literacy from an entrepreneurial mindset. The instructional process acts to engage students in entrepreneurial role playing; however, EES, Inc. recognizes that our audience must, as a prerequisite, master the essential personal financial literacy skills before taking on any risk-taking endeavor.

Immersing students in the fundamental aspects of an entrepreneurial mindset and the unlimited opportunities it can provide, students who complete this course will be able to:

-  Master financial literacy skills as a prerequisite to any risk-taking endeavor

-  Establish goal-setting and time management skills and identify resources and determine the steps required to accomplish their goals

-  Develop critical thinking skills enabling them to identify and evaluate entrepreneurial opportunities

-  Understand the process that enables entrepreneurs to transform a simple idea into a sustainable success

-  Establish goals, identify resources and determine the steps required to accomplish their goals

-  Identify and job shadow local entrepreneurs and business owners within their own communities

-  Understand and apply fundamental aspects of entrepreneurial thinking across disciplines and as a means of personal empowerment

The ERO™: Starting Where We Are


www.FinancialLiteracy.biz

Currently, this two-semester capstone entrepreneurship course is being transformed on the Financial Literacy webpage. Eighteen modules have been drafted, which include reading assignments, case studies, vocabulary lists, comprehensive web resources, and homework assignments. However, Module 1: Start Where You Are is the only module available in a textbook, workbook and instructor’s manual format.

Napkin drawings, a concept borrowed from Dan Roam, author of The Back of the Napkin, are used to effectively communicate more complex entrepreneurship and accounting principles to our audiences.

Our Goals for the Future

EES, Inc. has lofty goals for future expansion. The goal is to complete core Modules 0-5 for fall 2015 and post them online in a marketable format for students, educators, homeschooled patrons and encore entrepreneurs.

Another market niche being researched is the Hispanic small business owners. Our research tells us that there are more than three million Hispanic business owners in the U.S. We would welcome the opportunity to add this market to our student population.

Beyond this time frame, our goals include more beta-testing, joint venture partnerships, and completion of the remaining twelve modules, currently in a rough draft.

The ERO™ Portal

The website will include access to a vibrant online entrepreneurial learning community that enables participants and facilitators to share their knowledge and experience with other entrepreneurs and educators within their own communities, as well as others across the country and around the world.

www.FinancialLiteracy.biz

The ERO™ Modules

The modular format can be easily modified to meet a variety of delivery schedules from an intensive boot camp style program to a two-semester capstone course; and can be delivered in a traditional, blended, or virtual classroom.

Traditional classroom

Traditional classroom delivery provides facilitator access to the online course materials. Each student receives a hard copy of the textbook and student workbook which includes multiple choice test questions, discussion topics, individual and group assignments.

The traditional classroom delivery is divided into daily lesson plans designed to stimulate interactive classroom discussions. The individual student workbook enables the student to access the test items, discussion topics, personal reflections and problem-based learning assignments.

Blended classroom

The blended classroom delivery enables students, as well as the facilitator, the same access as the traditional classroom, in addition to a unique passcode that enables the student to access the online course materials.

Blended classroom participants can interact with online tests, discussion topics, personal reflections and problem-based learning assignments online or via the student workbook.

Facilitated online

Facilitated online delivery offers both flexibility and convenience with the potential to engage students globally. Offering facilitated online delivery, both student and facilitator gain access to online course materials along with a copy of the text materials. Students can view the materials anytime, anywhere to complete the lessons on their own time, and at their own pace. The facilitator can use the online learning community to host group discussions and peer-to-peer learning.

Why Financial Literacy?

EES, Inc. defines financial literacy as the ability to understand how money works in the world: how someone manages to earn or make it, how that person manages it, how s/he invests it (turn it into more) and how that person donates it to help others. More specifically, it refers to the set of skills and knowledge that allows an individual to make informed and effective decisions with all of their financial resources. 

Campaign Budget


In order for The ERO™ to become a reality we are seeking funding in the amount of $73,800 to provide the five core modules in our online portal. To accomplish this we still need to secure the proper technology and complete the editing and uploading of the remaining modules. Once this is in place, we plan on being classroom-ready by August 1, 2015. Your help in making this reality is greatly appreciated.


Rewards

Follow Team ERO™

Donald F. Connelly- entrepreneurialrecipe@gmail.com

Ingrid Rounds Hardy- gracious.growth@gmail.com

Victoria M. Chu- vickymchu@gmail.com

...and look for us on:

·  Google+

·  Pinterest

·  Teachers Pay Teachers
story_txt:
Our Mission
The
mission of Entrepreneurship Educational Services (EES), Inc. and its partners
is:
To provide animated, highly interactive,
online entrepreneurship curricula anytime, anywhere.
Teaching financial literacy is the essence
of our internet instructional resources and ongoing services for secondary
education, home schooled, and encore entrepreneurs.
The
Problem
Aspiring entrepreneurs, regardless of their
stage in life, face many challenges.
· 
Most graduating seniors enter the workforce
financially illiterate
· 
80% of educators admit to lacking the skills
necessary to teach financial literacy courses
· 
Homeschool parents struggle to find quality
curriculum for their students
· 
Encore entrepreneurs are in need of an
affordable, yet flexible curriculum to fit their lifestyle needs
The ERO™
Solution
Entrepreneurship Educational Services
(EES), Inc. has accepted the challenge to provide a web-based curriculum to
address these needs. 
The Entrepreneurial Recipe Online (ERO) ™ is a revolutionary new online learning
program designed to inspire and educate students in the fundamentals of
mastering financial literacy from an entrepreneurial mindset. The instructional
process acts to engage students in entrepreneurial role playing; however, EES,
Inc. recognizes that our audience must, as a prerequisite, master the essential
personal financial literacy skills before taking on any risk-taking endeavor.
Immersing
students in the fundamental aspects of an entrepreneurial mindset and the
unlimited opportunities it can provide, students who complete this course will
be able to:
-  Master financial
literacy skills as a prerequisite to any risk-taking endeavor
-  Establish goal-setting
and time management skills and identify resources and determine the steps required
to accomplish their goals
-  Develop critical
thinking skills enabling them to identify and evaluate entrepreneurial
opportunities
-  Understand the process
that enables entrepreneurs to transform a simple idea into a sustainable
success
-  Establish goals, identify resources and
determine the steps required to accomplish their goals
-  Identify and job shadow local entrepreneurs and
business owners within their own communities
-  Understand and apply
fundamental aspects of entrepreneurial thinking across disciplines and as a means
of personal empowerment
The
ERO™: Starting Where We Are
www.FinancialLiteracy.biz
Currently,
this two-semester capstone entrepreneurship course is being transformed on the
Financial Literacy webpage. Eighteen modules have been drafted, which include
reading assignments, case studies, vocabulary lists, comprehensive web
resources, and homework assignments. However, Module 1: Start Where You Are is the only module available in a
textbook, workbook and instructor’s manual format.
Napkin
drawings, a concept borrowed from Dan Roam, author of The Back of the Napkin, are used to effectively communicate more
complex entrepreneurship and accounting principles to our audiences. 
Our
Goals for the Future
EES,
Inc. has lofty goals for future expansion. The goal is to complete core Modules
0-5 for fall 2015 and post them online in a marketable format for students,
educators, homeschooled patrons and encore entrepreneurs. 
Another
market niche being researched is the Hispanic small business owners. Our research
tells us that there are more than three million Hispanic business owners in the
U.S. We would welcome the opportunity to add this market to our student
population.
Beyond
this time frame, our goals include more beta-testing, joint venture
partnerships, and completion of the remaining twelve modules, currently in a
rough draft. 
The
ERO™ Portal
The website will include access to a vibrant online
entrepreneurial learning community that enables participants and facilitators
to share their knowledge and experience with other entrepreneurs and educators
within their own communities, as well as others across the country and around
the world.

modular format can be easily modified to meet a variety of delivery schedules

story:
Our Story

The School:

The Talimi Haq School was established in 1998 as an innovative learning center for the children of the working poor in Howrah, an industrial suburb of Kolkata, India. The school is located in the Priya Manna Basti (a slum settlement, characterized by cramped housing, poor environmental conditions, near non-existent health care and chronic poverty.)

The current enrollment at the school is approximately 250 students, ranging in age from 3 to 16. The primary focus of the school is not only on establishing vital language, literacy and numeracy skills, but just as importantly on the arts, including music, dance and drama, and, overall, on creating an environment conducive to developing the self-respect and dignity that make healthy, well-rounded and civic-minded individuals.

For these children, many of whom enter the labor market by the age of 13, the Talimi Haq School represents a privileged (and singular) space of safety, caring, nurturing, and support otherwise lacking in their lives. 

Head Teacher: Amina Khatoon

The teacher in charge at the school, Amina Khatoon (pictured above), has been working at the school since its inception 17 years ago.  She, along with her crew of seven other community based teachers, share a truly remarkable dedication to the mission of bringing education to the poor and marginalized children of Howrah. Ms. Khatoon received an Infochange Media Fellowship, and published a series articles on life in the Priya Manna Basti, and the challenges of education, economy and health-care that the mostly poor, Muslim residents of the slum face. Nothing describes the problems and promise of education in the Priya Manna Basti better than Amina's own words, published in a series of articles here:

http://infochangeindia.org/urban-india/see-the-city-from-here/48-bigha-zameen-the-birth-of-priya-manna-basti.html

Our Current Undertakings:

With your support, and according to plans well worked out in advance by the teachers at Talimi Haq, the school plans to initiate two new education and empowerment projects: 1.) a sewing school and 2.) a health clinic that will provide regular access to reproductive health care for teenage girls, as well as classes for these same girls in self and community-health care.

These two projects, together, will provide a platform for the girls of the Talimi Haq School to secure better opportunities for their own futures, both in terms of economy and health care.

The Sewing School:

Tailoring is a traditional trade in Bengal, but it is also a skill that, because of a lack of resources, few young people are presently learning, particularly in the slums. Sewing is valued by the women of the community because it enables them to bring money into the home, and can also help sustain young women and their children in the (all to common) event of the loss of or abandonment by a spouse.

The sewing school will produce handicrafts and other tailored goods for sale through established fair trade channels. This money will go towards the operation of the school and the eventual self-sustainability of the project. It will also provide girls a very marketable skill, which will allow them a measure of economic independence, under otherwise constrained circumstances.

We are asking you to help out in providing the funds for space, machinery and personnel to get this project off the ground.

Health Care:

In this community women typically marry and start having children at a young age, sometimes as early as 14 years old. By the time they are in the mid-twenties many women in the community are entirely overburdened with the struggle of maintaining families with an average of five children per household. In addition, malnutrition, poor sanitation, and lack of proper health care results in high rates of maternal mortality.

The health project envisioned by Ms. Khatoon will provide for a bi-weekly health clinic, with a certified gynecological doctor, who will give the girls regular examinations and screenings, as well as family planning counseling. The project will also involve a course, run by Ms. Khatoon and two other women teachers at the school, in self-health care and empowerment. This project will be overseen in consultation with Dr. Joia Mukherjee, Harvard University Department of Global Health and Social Medicine and Medical Director of the world-renowned organization Partner's in Health (PIH):

http://ghsm.hms.harvard.edu/person/faculty/joia-mukherjee

 Why we need $19,875 

Your donation will help us to run the sewing and health education project for two years. We can purchase sewing machines and offer sewing classes for $4,960. We can offer at least six health education workshops for $2,375, and for another $2,750 gives women free access to a female doctor and assistant for women's personal health matters. General supplies, room rental and local staff support for two years will be $9,790. 

Two years allows time for future donors to witness the project's value to the community, for students to start producing garments that can be sold to raise funds, and for us to develop a sustainable funding model.

Please see a detailed budget for these programs below.

Giving

We are happy to accept any donations big or small. All donations will go directly to these projects without administrative overhead of any sort. The organizers of this campaign do not have charitable status, and as such we regret that your donations may not be tax deductible.

 For birthdays, Christmas, Hanukkah, or other special occasions give the gift of a donation in the person's name, For a gift of $200 receive a present sewn by the young women you have empowered with your contribution. For other perks and dedicated giving see our Perks page.

If we raise less than $19,875 we will offer as many sewing and health classes and hours of medical counseling as funds allow. Meanwhile we will explore alternative funding sources.

The Challenges to Overcome

We will begin at once to work on a sustainable funding model. In India, this is much easier to do for a project that is underway. Local businesses people, politicians, and community leaders already respect Talimi Haq School. When they see how the sewing classes and health education are being received by the community they will be encouraged to support our project. But we will not rely on donations. We believe that self-sustaining money can be raised by selling items through a fair trade NGO.

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you are unable to make a donation now. You can still help us to achieve our goals by telling your family and friends about our campaign and encouraging them to visit our Indiegogo website to make a donation. Get the word out through Facebook and other social media!

Ask to be put on our Friends List so we can send you links to videos and photos of the project and regular updates.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Budget

Our Two Year Budget for Talimi Haq Sewing & Health Education Project

Our Crowd funding goal                                  $19,875 (1,192,500 INR)

Our expense for running the full project   $19,875 (1,192,500 INR)

Overall Project Expenses

·  School staff expenses (24 mos.)              $2,660 (159,600 INR)

·  Room rental for all                                         $6,290 (377,600 INR)

·  Miscellaneous supplies                                $840 (50,400 INR)

Sewing Classes

·  Sewing class teacher & teacher assist   $2,800 (168,000 INR)

·  Purchase six sewing machines                  $800 (48,000 INR)

·  Sewing materials and equipment             $1,360 (81,680 INR)

Health Education Workshops

·  Two health care workers                              $2,200 (138,000 INR)

·  Health education materials                         $175 (10,000 INR)

Health care clinics

·  Woman doctor: individual counseling      $2,400 (144,000 INR)

·  Materials and medications                           $350 (21,000 INR)

story:
About Us

We are a team of five excited students from Florida State University, members of a student nonprofit organization called Global Peace Exchange. Our goal is to spend 8 weeks in Summer 2015 working in a business incubator in Kigali, Rwanda. We will work firsthand with the women who have been accepted into the employment program, offering advice and mentorship as they plan and initiate the businesses they wish to launch in their communities. Our curriculum will cover many business topics, from ideation, to marketing, to data management and administration.

Global Peace Exchange is a nonprofit that has been creating and running summer service projects like this one for many years at Florida State University. The Rwanda project is just one of four projects planned for this summer, with other teams traveling to Nepal, Ghana, and Cambodia. The organization chooses qualified volunteers for each project, trains them for specific tasks, and raises funds throughout the year to send the volunteers abroad. Previous trips have left many sustainable projects and long-lasting relationships with local communities and organizations, in several countries around the world.

To follow along, and for more information on Global Peace Exchange, visit: https://www.facebook.com/globalpeaceexchangefsu


About The Partner Organization

Duhugurane, meaning “Let us learn from each other” in Kinyarwanda, aims to teach young women ages 18-25 to discover and utilize their personal and professional strengths, recognize their abilities and improve their knowledge and self confidence so they may lead more sustainable lives.

Duhugurane is an organization within Belay Global, and is working to empower local entrepreneurs in contributing to guiding their communities out of poverty. This is why they have constructed a teaching program that prepares people to begin local businesses. The program is broken down into four phases, Phase Three being the incubation period that we will be participating in, offering business training for the entrepreneurs and their future enterprises.

For more information on Duhu, visit: http://www.belayglobal.org/duhu/


What We Need From You

Our fundraising goal of $5,000 is what it takes to help fund all five of us to participate in this trip. It will be used for airfare, visas, vaccines, housing, food, and some necessary supplies for the business incubator. Any size donation makes a difference for us, and our limited student wealth, and greatly helps in facilitating this project.

Our team believes strongly in precise budgeting and bootstrapping, so you can trust that we have taken all costs into consideration, and have planned our fundraising goals in accordance with realistic financial needs!


The Impact

Our project will assist the participating women in launching businesses that can serve their communities, and be sustained for many years to come. In addition, we will be conducting research studies on business incubator methodology, the trade economy of Rwanda and its people, and the sustainability of a social enterprise for a produce business that operates on a global scale. We want to accomplish, learn, and contribute as much as possible during our time in this unique country.


Please contribute what you can and help spread the word!


Stay in Touch

We’ll be posting updates throughout our trip on this Facebook page:

story:
Hey Everyone! Some of you may know me already, but for those who don't.....

    My name is Kathleen Herles (I'm in the middle with the curly hair wearing all black). I'm 24 years old. I was raised in church, but It wasn't until about a year ago that I've finally made the decision to give my life to God 100%.  God has  revealed himself to me in ways that I've never seen before. Moving forward now from this decision, I want everything that I do to glorify Him a by constantly asking myself what MORE can I do for Jesus.  I don't know what God has in his will for me , but what I can tell you is that I have been accepted to be a part of A missions trip organized by the Apostolic Youth Corps and have a chance to spread the gospel globally! 
    I am going to Ireland, May 29th to June 8th,  to assist missionaries Joe & Fanny Cooney. Along with others, we will be ministering in their church, partaking in street evangelism and preachings, daily group devotions, outreach, and participate in a new church plant during the Belfast Conference! 
     Yes, I will be ministering, but I know that this experience will  be a life changing experience for me spiritually, mentally, and. physically.  I'm. so excited to see  what  God has planned to teach me through this experience.
    The Cost of the  trip is 3,550. My first payment of $500 is due by Februray 15th . The second payment. of $1700 is due by  March 15th. The last payment of  $1200. is due by May  15th. It would be greatly appreciated if you could support me in this . If you do , you are not only supporting just me but also His Kingdom and you will surely be blessed. 
     Every little bit counts. If I raise more than my goal I will give  what I don't need to others from my youth group who have also applied and have been accepted to go to places like Japan, Botswana, France, Nicaragua, & India! 
    You can read more about AYC. by visiting apostolicyouthcorps.com and more about  The Church on Upci.org 

Thank you so much for your time. Be blessed in Jesus' name!
story_txt:
Hey Everyone! Some of you may know me already, but for those who don't.....
    My name is Kathleen Herles (I'm in the middle with the curly hair wearing all black). I'm 24 years old. I was raised in church, but It wasn't until about a year ago that I've finally made the decision to give my life to God 100%.  God has  revealed himself to me in ways that I've never seen before. Moving forward now from this decision, I want everything that I do to glorify Him a by constantly asking myself what MORE can I do for Jesus.  I don't know what God has in his will for me , but what I can tell you is that I have been accepted to be a part of A missions trip organized by the Apostolic Youth Corps and have a chance to spread the gospel globally! 
    I am going to Ireland, May 29th to June 8th,  to assist missionaries Joe & Fanny Cooney. Along with others, we will be ministering in their church, partaking in street evangelism and preachings, daily group devotions, outreach, and participate in a new church plant during the Belfast Conference! 

     Yes, I will be ministering, but I know that this experience will  be a life changing experience for me spiritually, mentally, and. physically.  I'm. so excited to see  what  God has planned to teach me through this experience.
    The Cost of the  trip is 3,550. My first payment of $500 is due by Februray 15th . The second payment. of $1700 is due by  March 15th. The last payment of  $1200. is due by May  15th. It would be greatly appreciated if you could support me in this . If you do , you are not only supporting just me but also His Kingdom and you will surely be blessed. 
     Every little bit counts. If I raise more than my goal I will give  what I don't need to others from my youth group who have also applied and have been accepted to go to places like Japan, Botswana, France, Nicaragua, & India!     You can read more about AYC. by visiting apostolicyouthcorps.com and more about  The Church on Upci.org   Thank you so much for your time. Be blessed in Jesus' name!

story:
Dear friends and family,

  In the summer of 2015 I am planning on attending a service learning trip in South Korea. As most of you know I am a social work major and a huge component of being successful in this field involves hands on experience helping those in need. The purpose of this trip is to engage in social work practice while also gaining knowledge about what it is like to work with diverse populations and adapt to the differences abroad.

  While in Korea I will have the opportunity to work approximately 30 hours a week in an agency that helps children and youth with developmental disabilities. It is an opportunity to give my knowledge and compassion to the people of South Korea and immerse myself into their community.

  I am incredibly passionate about the field of social work. For as long as I can remember volunteering has been my passion and the one true thing that brings me complete happiness. In the process of my studies I am trying to acquire as many experiences and opportunities to learn skills to become the best social worker possible and have all of the resources to promote change in the lives of those who are suffering and in the world. Through going to Korea I will gain these valuable skills and experiences that I hope to use in our community one day.

  I will leave for Korea the May 31st and be there for one month. I will be attending with a professor of social work who is actually from Korea along with many other Chico State students. We will spend our week days volunteering at a variety of human service agencies and on the weekends we will be immersed into the culture with the natives. I truly can’t explain how excited I am that this opportunity has come before me, the benefits that it has on my education and my life are numerous.

  As my friends and family I am asking if you would like to be a part of my journey through a small sponsorship or simply through your prayers and positive thoughts. I cannot wait to embark on this journey and create some positive change in the lives of those who are struggling in Korea; however I am even more thrilled to become a social worker who is equipped to handle all that is thrown at me and help the people of our community. If you would like to be a part of my journey you can donate here. As a sponsor I will keep you informed about my time in Korea and when I return I would like to share with you my experience.

   Love always, Mackenzie Lovie

story:
Short Summary

Our son was diagnosed with Autism 6 years ago. Life was difficult and stressful having to plan around all the issues that children on the Spectrum have. Our daughter, who was 9 at the time, always seemed to be left out, as we had to cater more for our son who was very rigid instead of our easy going girl.  We longed to be able to find a way to enjoy both our children and to be able to connect as a family. We chose camping as a way to accomplish this as it met our financial, time and therapeutic needs.  Through camping, our son has been able to manage many of his sensory overload issues, such as coping with insects, heat and cold, using an unfamiliar toilet and becoming used to getting dirty and enjoying natural experiences. He also had to learn how to cope with many unstructured activities and to not be so rigid in a routine; it was ok for him to not be in bed by 7:30pm as there were marshmallows to roast and stars to explore. He also had no sense of danger and would often run away when he became overly anxious. We therefore used camping and our experience with wilderness survival to teach him how to become aware of dangers around him, teach him basic survival techniques and also how to self sooth and calm himself in order to manage his anxiety. These are just some of the things we want to share with and teach families in our camping workshops.

We have found the perfect property to fulfil our dreams. It is 22 acres of beautiful bushland set in the foothills of the Alpine mountains in Victoria, Australia. We are asking for donations in the amount of $250,000. This money will go towards securing a loan for the total amount of the purchase price of the property which is currently priced at $595,000. The money raised through this campaign will go towards purchasing the property and doing the necessary works to make it a safe and secure area to run these camping workshops. In order to make the property safe, it needs a significant amount of maintenance and upgrades such as clearing of undergrowth and building a toilet block to accommodate the campers participating in the workshops. In the event we don't reach our full campaign goal, any money raised will be used to help secure the property with a loan from a financial institution.

The Impact

You may ask why do we want to do this and what qualifications do we have to be successful in our endeavour? Raising a child with Autism is a daily struggle and each child on the Spectrum is unique in their abilities and challenges. We do understand this. Our aim is to help as many families as we can to find a positive outlet in an activity all of the family can enjoy together. In Victoria alone, there is a minimum of a six month waiting list for families of children with special needs to partake in respite camps or farm stays. That is a long time to wait to participate in any kind of activity that can cater for their needs. Raising a child with additional needs takes a toll on families and many of these families do not have a lot of additional money to be able to take holidays. Camping can be a cheap and convenient way for a family to take a much needed break whenever their schedule allows, which is another reason we have been enjoying this activity for 6 years.

So who are we? We are 2 families that have been the best of friends for 8 years who will be operating as a partnership. We have been together through the diagnosis of our son, the challenges and the successes. We camp together regularly as a family group. Between the 4 adults our formal qualifications include a former member of the US Army Special Forces who now owns and operates his own Private Security Firm specialising in Close Personal Protection and Physical Environment Protection. There are also 2 former nurses with over 20 years combined experience with specialties in Paediatric and Mental Health nursing. Two of us are also Certified Trainers, one with a Masters in Public Health who specialises in Community Education. Finally, we have a Builder with demolition and large rig experience which will be useful when making upgrades and ongoing maintenance to the property. As an added assistance with our camps, we have a Licensed Family Therapist who is also an Occupational Therapist with special training in Autism Spectrum Disorders who has expressed interest in participating in these camping workshops. 

Risks & Challenges

There is never any thing without risk and challenges.

Our number one challenge, is to raise enough money to purchase and upgrade the property to make it the safe environment we wish to offer.  In the event we do not raise enough money for this property, then we will look at purchasing a different property that will again allow us to conduct these learning workshops.  We believe in what we are doing and know it works as it has worked for our family.

The next challenge we will face will be making the property safe and secure for families.  The property is at the foothills of the Alpine region in Victoria and does back on to a state forest.  As avid campers and outdoors people, we know what to look for and will remove, if possible, anything that may pose any type of risk for the families so they will have a safe and enjoyable stay.  This includes erecting a new fence around the property and clearing of underbrush. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone has the financial means to donate money to our campaign.  Any help you can offer in getting our story out to the world and help publicise our campaign would be a tremendous help.  Just because you cannot financially support us, you can still support us by spreading the word on social media and by word of mouth.  If you know an organisation that may be interested in our campaign, please let them know about us.  Don't forget to use sharing tools right here at Indiegogo.com.

story:
Our mission 

The John Kearns School of Log Building, named after the late coachbuilder and carpenter, John Noel Kearns, will establish a school of traditional carpentry in our woodland in Mid-Wales, focusing on Scandanavian and Eastern European log building.

Log building is a traditional way to create beautiful, creative, energy-efficient buildings in an environmentally friendly way, using hand-working techniques, keeping power tools and industrial processing in proper perspective and allowing the whole process to happen off-grid.

We want to bring a new dimension to UK forestry, timber construction, the rural economy, and skills and training, while also providing a platform for outdoor learning and outreach work with disadvantaged groups in our local community. 

We believe a culture of log building will invigorate local timber markets, complement existing forestry practice and provide scope for its development. 

The School will be co-ordinated by Forester and Carpenter Jack Kearns and Community Outreach Worker Alistair McAuley who has extensive experience working with vulnerable and disadvantaged members of the community in developing positive change.

Our funding goals

We are looking to raise a minimum of £20,000, although if we hit further targets (£45,000 and £63,000) we will be able to achieve a lot more in a shorter space of time. We have already raised £1,000 via our own website.

With £20,000 we will be able to purchase a tractor, winch and timber-trailer with which we can begin to extract timber from our woodland. This will not only mean we can start work on building the hand-hewn, timber-framed barn which will act as the main classroom and workshop for the school, but it will also mean we can sell timber and create a sustainable income for the school from the outset. If we hit this target all the courses in our perks section will definitely go ahead - if we don't, people who have signed up to them will be refunded: no ifs, no buts.

By reaching our goal of £45,000 we will be able to carry out groundworks, lay foundations and build the barn, although at this level of funding we will still rely on a large amount of volunteer time.

If we can reach £63,000 we will be able to pay foresters and carpenters a fair and proper wage to build the barn, and we'll be able to purchase hand tools and other resources for students - and therefore be ready for courses to start this September.

What happens next

Working from our woodland barn, we will run a range of log building courses and outdoor learning experiences, working with John Neeman Tools to bring master carpenter teachers from Latvia, where there is a long standing tradition of log building.

We teach in a style that promotes collaboration and encourages students to act upon their own intuition to develop confidence and creativity.

An understanding of forestry is fundamental to good log building. We teach forestry and carpentry hand-in-hand, going through the fundamentals of growing, selecting and extracting trees from the forest, instilling respect and appreciation for its place in nature and the work involved in its extraction. 

In the future we will work with other organisations to provide education and training for young people and support others in our local community.

To be kept updated on our progress as we begin preparing timber for the barn, please like our facebook page and follow us on twitter. 

For more detailed information on the School, our ethos and our plans, please see our website: www.kearnslogschool.com.


Many Thanks

The John Kearns School of Log Building Co-ordinators

Jack Kearns - 07523 983 949

Alistair McAuley - 07572 112 602

kearnslogschool@gmail.com

www.facebook.com/kearnslogschool

  • www.twitter.com/kearnslogschool

story:
Sam's Story

My little sister Samantha has made the wonderful decision to try and help others less fortunate than herself. She has decided to travel to Malawi in order to teach in a small school in a derelict town. Samantha has an enormous capacity for love and her kind, sweet nature is the reason she felt obligated to help those who cannot help themselves. Whilst in Malawi Samantha will teach her very own class, helping children who have very little to no resources how to read and write. The only way Samantha will be able to help these children is with your help! If you are able to contribute even the smallest amount to Samantha's fund it would be appreciated and go a long way to helping her achieve her goal. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • At the moment I am trying to raise at least £500 and if we reach that goal we will be delighted!
  • I am currently taking part in a sponsored fast and will also be doing a sponsored leg wax (which as Samantha's brother I think you'll agree will be rather painful)

The Impact

The impact of your donation will have an effect on hundreds of children whom Samantha will help. These children are thrilled at the idea of someone coming to fulfil their growing educational needs. Imagine the joy on a small child's face because they are able to write their first word or read their first sentence! You could help make that change with a small donation!

story:
Update December 1, 2015

Rebuilding Oscar International Film School and Nepal landed in premiere magazine Vanity Fair.  This article by Mark Edward Harris was sparked by writer and supporter Eric Hiss and our collective efforts. Thank you all for being a big part of this special story.

Yatin Parkhani

Update October 17, 2015

As our formal Indiegogo campaign winds down today, I want to thank you all for helping raise over $1400 and one donated 5D camera package (worth $1500!). I will be traveling to Nepal (at my own expense) in early November to deliver the contributions to the film school.  In the meanwhile, tax-deductible donations continue on US nonprofit WeOne's simpler, yet equally secure and dedicated donation page. 

Thank you all for being such generous beings

Yatin Parkhani


The Story

Amidst soaring Himalayan mountains and diverse cultures that fascinate the world, Nepal’s massive earthquake devastated that country’s only film school– Oscar International College of Film Studies. 

Today its 120 pupils study under tents and in temporary shelters; their camera gear largely destroyed and classrooms condemned. Now your US tax-deductible donation can help.


It was only when Oscar started in 2005 that locals began formally learning how to craft and share their own fascinating stories through filmmaking.

In this hard-pressed land, helping survivors rebuild lives is vital, but so too are the arts which give us deeper connections, understanding and joy.  In all of Nepal, Oscar is the sole college that teaches the art of film.

In the words of Oscar’s Dean, filmmaker Binod Paudel:

“Crisis can create wonderful stories and narrative in cinema. So, we just want to experiment with lowest technologies to get better output and show the world that less money can create something very creative and beautiful too.

We will be grateful even if we can get outdated equipment such as HD cameras, some inexpensive lights and audio recorders in working condition.”



The Bigger Picture

Together, via We One (an officially registered 501(c)3 nonprofit), we'll fund-raise and deliver several camera & light kits ($10,000), plus a year’s rent for classrooms while the campus rebuilds (another $10,000). Money goes a long way in Nepal and US donors' donations are tax-deductible. 

Being one of the world’s most affordable non-subsidized film schools (tuition is $1,400/year; while 20% of the students have need-based scholarships), Oscar’s never had a lot of equipment: a single Red digital cinema camera and several 5Ds (professional HD video cameras), yet its impressive alumni have achieved recognition at major film festivals like Venice, Busan and Berlin.

Now, with the earthquake having destroyed much of that equipment, your pledges and encouragement will make a huge difference for these students. 


Our Goals

After achieving and delivering one goal, we’ll focus on fulfilling the next.

First raise $10,000 for camera and production gear (your donations of used equipment are tax-deductible, contact us for more details);

Second raise another $10,000 for a year’s temporary classroom rent;

If together, we make our first 2 goals, then our final goal is in reach too.

Finally raise $60,000 to rebuild the main building in a creative, cost-effective, environmentally friendly and earthquake-resistant manner.

All net proceeds will go to these goals


More Details

SHORT-TERM GOAL:

Raise $10,000 to partially replace and deliver equipment destroyed in the earthquake, including:

3-4 Canon 5D or 7D DSLR camera-kits (used equipment donations are tax-deductible)

2-3 basic light kits

2 audio recorders (used equipment donations are tax-deductible)

Since the earthquake, the entire student body has been sharing a single 5D camera to shoot their practical exams.


MEDIUM-TERM GOAL:

Raise $10,000 to pay for a year’s rent of temporary classroom facilities while the school rebuilds. 

With the monsoon season upon us and then the Himalayan Winter approaching, funds will be used to rent space to temporarily house the college’s classes while rebuilding begins.


FINAL GOAL:

In the long run, funds will be used to rebuild the college classrooms and studio in a clever, environmentally friendly way.  This additional $60,000 will complete the project.  Money goes a long way in Nepal.

“My perception about budget is different. I want to build the building
creatively not lavishly. We do not need a lavish or standard kind of
building. We are artists and we know how to survive in bad condition.

I want to make our simple building environmentally friendly, earthquake
resistant and good-looking in very low cost. I have been researching related
construction types and I can say that within 60 thousand US dollars, we can build such a building for 150 students."

– Dean Binod Paudel

 

Donate Multiple Ways

Working with We One (an officially registered 501(c)3 nonprofit), Oscar can also accept online donations securely at We One’s own website, where American Donors’ contributions are also tax deductible.

DONATE YOUR USED CAMERA GEAR (It’s Tax-Deductible):

Additionally, if you have gently-used Canon 5D cameras, lenses or gear and are based in LA, the Bay-area or South Florida, We One can collect these donations AND provide tax write-offs for fair market value.

To arrange for donating equipment, contact We One's Yatin Parkhani at yatin@beyondmaya.com or call +1 (718) 312-9327

Note: 5D camera donations are valued at Room Naming Rights reward-level.



Final Thoughts

Oscar's film students come from remote valleys and soaring mountains, Himalayan cities and farming villages  – places many of us will never reach. But combining the ancient power of story with modern motion-picture tools, these young filmmakers can take us into their own fascinating worlds.

Together, let's give them that chance.

“The earthquake has taught us a good lesson in being human. Helping each other in your capacity is always joyful and peaceful movement for the life [sic]. So, our motto would be: 'Creating filmmakers in Nepal and for the world in an artistic, humane way and at very low cost.'"

– Dean Binod Paudel

Caveats

The cost of transporting and delivering camera packages to Nepal, and any import duty will be covered through the funds raised. Update October 17, 2015: Please note that We One board member Yatin Parkhani will be travelling to Nepal at his own expense to deliver the first batch of gear and that will hugely reduce any delivery costs (import duties excepted).

For donors selecting Room or Building naming rights rewards: if the amount raised via indiegogo is not enough to rebuild the campus building, then these rewards will be implemented once the college is able to raise additional funds to complete construction.  Any Diamond-level donation of $30,000 will be held and secured in the WE ONE bank account and released to Oscar International College of Film Studies upon initiation of building reconstruction projects.

While Oscar International College of Film Studies is established, popular, has a stable student body, and continues operations, there is no guarantee of the college's functional capacities in the future (i.e. a natural, financial, social, or political disasters or obstacles could occur).   
Credit card donors from outside of the United States may be charged an additional currency conversion fee by their own credit cards. Please factor this into your donation if your credit card is a non-US one.  
Note that US donors' donations ARE tax-deductible, but that non-US donors' donations may not be tax-deductible (please check in your own countries).

About Us

WE ONE  Founded by Kent Sokmensuer, We One is a US-registered 501(c)3 nonprofit and private charitable operating foundation (FEIN # 264472846).  With compassion for all, it focuses on helping communities in South Asia with sustainability & assists individual struggling Americans in the United States.

OSCAR INTERNATIONAL  Educating 120 students in its accredited three-years-bachelor’s in filmmaking program, and associated with Nepal’s flagshipTribhuvan University, Oscar is an institution of higher education empowering Nepal’s new generation of storytellers with filmic knowledge, tools and camaraderie. With affordable annual tuition fees under $1,400 US, and a robust need-based scholarship program, Oscar International has carefully built a student body that reflects Nepal's diversity, ambitions and dreams.


Notable Alumni include:

Min Bahadur Bham– Venice International Film Festival (Official Selection), Busan International Film Festival (Official Selection), Berlin Talent Campus

Joes Pandey – South Asia Film Festival (Best Debut Director)

Anup Poudel – World Democracy Film Competition (Winner) awarded by Hillary Clinton (US Sec’y of State)


Contacts

Yatin Parkhani:  Filmmaker and boardmember, We One   yatin@beyondmaya.com  +1 (718) 312-9327 (USA)   [Press and media inquiries welcome]

Kent Sokmensuer:  Founder and Chairman, We One   

friend@weone.us

Mr. Nawa Nidhi Dahal:  

Senior Administrator, 

Oscar International College of Film Studies  

mail@oscar.edu.np 

+977 98 41291572 (Nepal)
story_txt:
Update December 1, 2015
Rebuilding Oscar International Film School and Nepal landed in premiere magazine Vanity Fair.  This article by Mark Edward Harris was sparked by writer and supporter Eric Hiss and our collective efforts. Thank you all for being a big part of this special story.
Yatin ParkhaniUpdate October 17, 2015
As our formal Indiegogo campaign winds down today, I want to thank you all for helping raise over $1400 and one donated 5D camera package (worth $1500!). I will be traveling to Nepal (at my own expense) in early November to deliver the contributions to the film school.  In the meanwhile, tax-deductible donations continue on US nonprofit WeOne's simpler, yet equally secure and dedicated donation page. 
Thank you all for being such generous beings
Yatin Parkhani

The Story
Amidst soaring Himalayan mountains and diverse cultures that fascinate the world, Nepal’s massive earthquake devastated that
country’s only film school– Oscar International College of Film Studies. 


Today its 120 pupils study under tents and in temporary shelters; their camera gear largely destroyed and classrooms condemned. Now your US tax-deductible donation can help.



It was only when Oscar started in 2005 that locals began formally learning how to craft and share their own fascinating stories through filmmaking.
In this hard-pressed land, helping survivors rebuild lives is vital, but so too are the arts which give us deeper connections, understanding and joy.  In all of Nepal, Oscar is the sole college that teaches the art of film.
In the
words of Oscar’s Dean, filmmaker Binod Paudel:

“Crisis can create wonderful stories and narrative in cinema. So, we just want to experiment with lowest technologies to get better output and show the world that less money can create something very creative and beautiful too.
We will be grateful even if we can get outdated equipment such as HD cameras, some inexpensive lights and audio recorders in working condition.”

   


The Bigger Picture 
Together, via We One (an officially registered 501(c)3 nonprofit), we'll fund-raise and deliver several camera & light kits ($10,000), plus a year’s rent for classrooms while the campus rebuilds (another $10,000). Money goes a long way in Nepal and US donors' donations are tax-deductible. 
Being one of the world’s most affordable non-subsidized
film schools (tuition is $1,400/year;
while 20% of
the students have need-based scholarships), Oscar’s never had a lot of
equipment: a single Red digital cinema camera and several 5Ds (professional HD video cameras), yet its impressive alumni have achieved
recognition at major film festivals like Venice, Busan and Berlin. 
Now, with the
earthquake having destroyed much of that equipment, your pledges and
encouragement will make a huge difference for these students. 


Our Goals

After
achieving and delivering one goal, we’ll focus on fulfilling the next.
First raise $10,000 for camera and production gear (your donations of used equipment are tax-deductible, contact us for more details); 
Second raise another $10,000 for a year’s
temporary classroom rent; 
If together, we make our first 2 goals, then
our final goal is in reach too.
Finally raise $60,000 to
rebuild the main building in a creative, cost-effective, environmentally friendly
and earthquake-resistant manner.
All net
proceeds will go to these goals 



More Details

SHORT-TERM GOAL:
Raise $10,000 to partially replace
and deliver equipment destroyed in the earthquake, including:
3-4
Canon 5D or 7D DSLR camera-kits (used equipment donations are tax-deductible)
2-3
basic light kits
2 audio
recorders (used equipment donations are tax-deductible)
Since
the earthquake, the entire student body has been sharing a single 5D camera to
shoot their practical exams.



MEDIUM-TERM GOAL:
Raise $10,000 to pay for a year’s
rent of temporary classroom facilities while the school rebuilds.  
With the
monsoon season upon us and then the Himalayan Winter approaching, funds will be
used to rent space to temporarily house the college’s classes while rebuilding
begins.



FINAL GOAL: 
In the
long run, funds will be used to rebuild the college classrooms and studio in a
clever, environmentally friendly way. 
This additional $60,000 will
complete the project.  Money goes a
long way in Nepal.
“My perception about budget is different. I want to build
the building
creatively not lavishly. We do not need a lavish
or standard kind of
building. We are artists and we know how to
survive in bad condition.
I want to make our simple building
environmentally friendly, earthquake
resistant and good-looking in very low cost. I
have been researching related
construction types and I can say that within 60 thousand US dollars, we can build such a building for 150 students."

– Dean Binod Paudel
  


Donate Multiple Ways

Working
with We One (an officially registered 501(c)3
nonprofit), Oscar can also accept online donations
securely at We One’s own website, where American Donors’ contributions are also tax deductible. 
DONATE YOUR USED CAMERA GEAR (It’s
Tax-Deductible):
Additionally,
if you have gently-used Canon 5D cameras, lenses or gear and are based
in LA, the Bay-area or South Florida, We One can collect these donations AND
provide tax write-offs for fair market value.
To arrange for donating equipment, contact We One's Yatin Parkhani at yatin@beyondmaya.com or call +1 (718) 312-9327
Note: 5D camera donations are valued at Room Naming Rights reward-level.





Final ThoughtsOscar's film students come from remote valleys and soaring
mountains, Himalayan cities and farming villages  – places many of
us will never reach. But combining the ancient power of story with modern
motion-picture tools, these young filmmakers can take us into their own fascinating worlds.
Together, let's give them that chance. 


“The earthquake has taught us a good lesson in being human. Helping each other in your
capacity is always joyful and peaceful movement for the life [sic]. So, our motto would be: 'Creating
filmmakers in Nepal and for the world in an artistic, humane way and at very low
cost.'"
– Dean Binod Paudel

Caveats
The cost of transporting and delivering camera packages to Nepal, and any import duty will be covered through the funds raised. Update October 17, 2015: Please note that We One board member Yatin Parkhani will be travelling to Nepal at his own expense to deliver the first batch of gear and that will hugely reduce any delivery costs (import duties excepted).
For donors selecting Room or Building naming rights rewards: if the amount raised via indiegogo is not enough to rebuild the campus building, then these rewards will be implemented once the college is able to raise additional funds to complete construction.  Any Diamond-level donation of $30,000 will be held and secured in the WE ONE bank account and released to Oscar International College of Film Studies upon initiation of building reconstruction projects. While Oscar International College of Film Studies is established, popular, has a stable student body, and continues operations, there is no guarantee of the college's functional capacities in the future (i.e. a natural, financial, social, or political disasters or obstacles could occur).

Please factor this into your donation if your credit card is a non-US one.  Note that US donors' donations ARE tax-deductible, but that non-US donors' donations may not be tax-deductible (please check in your own countries).

501(c)3 nonprofit and private charitable operating foundation (FEIN #

focuses on helping communities in South Asia with sustainability &

fees under $1,400 US, and a robust need-based scholarship program, Oscar

Director)

Sec’y of State)

story:
Hello my name is Jesse Dorsz and I have designed a series of educational coloring books for children aged 3-10 years of age, who are being raised by a single parent. In our current culture this is a very common event but children need to know that both parents love and care. My books have a moral issue that is resolved and key words that the reader will learn and add to their vocabulary, that are part of the lesson.

I have not been previously published but I have really great ideas and a test market in a school system, if I can self-publish a working sample. I need to pay the illustrator and the publication assistant and your contribution is critical. If I am successful, the potential to reach so many children, where one parent is absent, can have a major impact on teaching life's lessons and balancing that with a healthy home environment. Thank you.

story:
WHAT ARE WE LOOKING FOR…

AUD$12,000 to pay our project-related expenses to run a month-long entrepreneurship and wellbeing workshop for people living in the community of Lobitos, Peru. The money is needed to pay our flights, accommodation and project materials.  WHY THE LOBITOS COMMUNITY

Peru has many disadvantaged communities that lack essential things for a good quality of life. Lobitos is one of the many economically disadvantaged towns that lacks access to basic needs such as clean water, sewage system, quality education and opportunities for social inclusion and development. 

Despite their poor economic conditions, the town believes there is more to wellbeing and want to build their community from a wellbeing perspective. There is terrific entrepreneurial talent in Lobitos that can change the quality of life of the residents but also change the life path for their children.

WHAT WILL THE PROGRAM DO EXACTLY?

We will teach entrepreneurship and wellbeing workshops as part of a major Latin American research project which is investigating how to build communities based on eight dimensions of wellbeing: economic, social, cultural, material, psychological, spiritual, environmental, and physical. The program is already running in Colombia, Chile, and Ecuador.

We are scientifically investigating a new way to build communities – the wellbeing way.HOW IS THIS APPROACH DIFFERENT?

Many approaches just focus on the economic development of marginalized communities. While this is clearly important, this one-sided approach can cause other problems such as environmental damage, community fragmentation and loss of culture and spirituality. 

Our approach takes all these dimensions into account when helping the community plan its business and community development.

WHAT WILL BE THE OUTCOME?

  • 40+ local community members completing a program who rate their experiences as life changing and who are motivated to continue their journey;
  • Identification of areas of wellbeing strength and weakness in the community;
  • Identification of new business opportunities that can improve community wellbeing

WHAT HAPPENS WHEN WE LEAVE? 

SUSTAINABILITY STRATEGY

Long-term sustainability is achieved by:

  • Including a local permanently-based NGO (Waves for Development) in the training workshops who then assumes responsibility for ongoing community wellbeing goal setting and new business development;
  • Partnering with a local University with the view to building their social entrepreneurship curriculum which includes ongoing student projects in the Lobitos community;
  • Ongoing direct community training facilitated through us and the partner NGO and University. 

WHY INVEST IN US?

We have received specialist postgraduate training in how to link entrepreneurship and community wellbeing for marginalized communities. We are skilled in:

  • Teaching to low education communities in Latin America;
  • Knowledge of community wellbeing and its measurement;
  • Knowledge of entrepreneurship training.


WHY ARE WE ASKING FOR $12K & HOW ARE WE SPENDING IT? 

Our main expense are the flights...only in transportation from Brisbane, Australia to Lobito, Peru we are spending $10K. The other $2k are project execution expenses.  

** if you know an airline or a company who would be interested in donating the flights please send us a message!

story:
In just five short years, Open Fields will begin its 50th year, and our building will reach its 200th year - but only if we can keep the evil General Rot and Major Rot at bay! Help us fight the good fight and address much-needed building repairs so we can keep our school a safe and healthy place for the inquiring minds of curious kids.

Inside these historic walls on scenic Thetford Hill, Vermont, Open Fields School has fostered a life-long love of learning for nearly 45 years. Open Fields, founded by Jean K. Aull in 1971, treats students as individuals, in an atmosphere where they are free to do their very best, free from excessive competition with their peers, and free from the fear of failure.

Open Fields in the World

Open Fields students have attended colleges and universities including Bard, Bowdoin, Clemson, Cornell, Hampshire, Mount Holyoke, Smith, the Sorbonne, Stanford, UNH, UVM, Vassar, Wellesley, and more. But more importantly, they have gone on to create lives that are meaningful to them and to the world - as engineers, farmers, actors, environmentalists, dancers, social workers - often citing Open Fields as crucial in their development.

The Open Fields School building

This school building - formerly a harness shop, residence, and post office - is in a harsh New England environment, where the cold winters, snow, wind, rain, and sun have worked their way through the wood: Our exterior staircase was getting rickety; the window sills and clapboards on the back wall of the school were decaying; one sill, buried by winter after winter of snow, and spring after spring of wet rains, has rotted and needs replacing; and the roof, which has kept snow and rain out of the building for many a year, may not last much longer!

Project Expenses

  • Replace exterior stairs/porch/access to third floor: $4,500
  • Replace 8 windows on the east side of the building, replace siding as necessary, repair rot at the roofline: $7,500
  • Replace rotted sill on the north side of the building: $5,500
  • Remove and replace shingles on the roof, repairing any damage: $7,500

Other ways to contribute

  • Mail a check to Open Fields School, PO Box 53, Thetford, VT 05074, with "General Rot" in the memo line.
  • Donate at the Open Fields website
  • Stop by the school and hand over some cash. (But please call ahead!)

Help us name a room for Jean and/or Trina!

If you'd like, you can forgo your perk and designate your donation toward naming a room in memory of our founder, Jean K. Aull, and/or her partner and long-time school supporter, Trina Schart Hyman. Just let us know you'd like to contribute toward the Founder's Room!

All donations are tax-deductible to the extent allowable by law.
